Subpart D of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation in taxable years after 2009. The "Pain at the Pump Act" repeals the enhanced oil recovery credit for oil and gas companies and adjusts dollar amounts for inflation in taxable years after 2009 based on the GNP implicit price deflator. The Secretary must publish the inflation adjustment factor by April 1 each year. Section 196 of the Code is amended to renumber paragraphs. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, with certain exceptions. Basis reductions continue for credits before December 31, 2011. SEC. 102 repeals the credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells, while SEC. 103 repeals the expensing of intangible drilling and development costs. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 103 repeals the expensing of intangible drilling and development costs for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 104 repeals the deduction for tertiary injectants, and SEC. 105 repeals the exception to passive loss limitations for working interests in oil and gas properties. SEC. 106 repeals the percentage depletion for oil and gas wells for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 107 amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to disallow the deduction for income from domestic production activities related to oil and gas. This change applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 108 amends the Internal Revenue Code to change the amortization period for geological and geophysical expenditures from 24 months to 7 years, effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. Investment in clean energy programs is recommended by Congress using increased revenue from title I provisions. This includes funding for alternative fuel technology, advanced battery development, clean energy research, loan guarantee programs, weatherization assistance, and more.
